question: Solutions A, B, C and D are respectively 0.1 M glucose, 0.05 M NaCl, 0.05 M $BaCl_{2}$ and 0.1 M $AlCl_{3}$. Which one of the following pairs is isotonic? [MHT CET 2008]
question_latex: Solutions A, B, C and D are respectively 0.1 M glucose, 0.05 M $NaCl$, 0.05 M $BaCl_{2}$ and 0.1 M $AlCl_{3}$. Which one of the following pairs is isotonic? [MHT CET 2008]
solution: Isotonic solutions have same molar concentration of solute particles in solution. Molar concentration of particles in solution are 0.1 M in glucose, $2 \times 0.05$ M in $NaCl$, $3 \times 0.05$ in $BaCl_{2}$ and $4 \times 0.1$ in $AlCl_{3}$. Therefore, 0.1 M glucose and 0.05 M $NaCl$ solutions are isotonic.

question: Calculate the concentration of dissolved gas in water at 25°C if partial pressure of gas at same temperature is 0.15 atm. [$K_H = 0.15 mol dm^{-3} atm^{-1}$] [2025]
question_latex: Calculate the concentration of dissolved gas in water at $25^{\circ}C$ if partial pressure of gas at same temperature is 0.15 atm. $[K_{H}=0.15~moldm^{-3}atm^{-1}][2025]$
solution: Concentration of dissolved gas $= K_{H} \times P = 0.15~moldm^{-3}atm^{-1} \times 0.15~atm = 0.0225~moldm^{-3} = 0.0225 M$.

question: A 500 g toothpaste sample has 0.2 g fluoride. What is the concentration of F⁻ in ppm?
question_latex: A 500 g toothpaste sample has 0.2 g fluoride. What is the concentration of $F^{-}$ in ppm?
solution: ppm means parts per million. To find parts by mass of fluoride ion in 1 million parts by mass of the toothpaste: 500 g toothpaste contains 0.2 g fluoride, 1000000 g toothpaste contains $x$ g fluoride, then $\frac{500}{10^6} = \frac{0.2}{x} \Rightarrow x = \frac{0.2 \times 10^{6}}{500} = 400~ppm$.

question_latex: Which has the minimum freezing point?

question: Volume of water needed to mix with 10 mL N HCl to get 0.1 N HCl is
question_latex: Volume of water needed to mix with 10 mL N $HCl$ to get 0.1 N $HCl$ is
solution: $N_{1}V_{1}=N_{2}V_{2} \Rightarrow 10 \times 1 = 0.1 \times V_{2} \Rightarrow V_{2}=100~mL$. Hence, water needed to mix $= 100 - 10 = 90$ mL.

question: Calculate the solubility of gas in water at 1.2 atm and 25°C, if Henry's law constant is 0.145 mol dm⁻³ atm⁻¹ at 25°C. [MHT-CET 2022]

solution: Given: $P=1.2~atm, K_{H}=0.145~moldm^{-3}atm^{-1}$. According to Henry's law, $S = K_{H}P = 0.145~moldm^{-3}atm^{-1} \times 1.2~atm = 0.174~moldm^{-3}$.

question: The 'x' g nonelectrolyte solute having molar mass 164 g mol⁻¹ dissolved in 2 dm³ water. Calculate the value of 'x' if resulting solution has osmotic pressure 0.6 atm at 300 K. (R = 0.0821 dm³ atm K⁻¹ mol⁻¹) [2025]
question_latex: The 'x' g nonelectrolyte solute having molar mass $164~g~mol^{-1}$ dissolved in $2~dm^{3}$ water. Calculate the value of 'x' if resulting solution has osmotic pressure 0.6 atm at 300 K. ($R=0.0821~dm^{3}~atm~K^{-1}mol^{-1}$) [2025]
solution: Weight of non-electrolyte ($W_2$) = 'x' g. $M_2 = 164~g~mol^{-1}, V = 2~dm^{3}, \pi = 0.6~atm, T = 300~K, i=1$. $\pi = i \frac{W_2 RT}{M_2 V} \Rightarrow x = \frac{\pi \times M_2 \times V}{R \times T} = \frac{0.6 \times 164 \times 2}{0.0821 \times 300} = 7.99~g$.

question: Calculate the cryoscopic constant of solvent if 0.15 mol kg⁻¹ solution of nonvolatile solute having depression in freezing point 1.79 K. [MHT-CET 2024: PCB]
question_latex: Calculate the cryoscopic constant of solvent if $0.15~mol~kg^{-1}$ solution of nonvolatile solute having depression in freezing point 1.79 K. [MHT-CET 2024: PCB]
solution: Given: $m=0.15~mol~kg^{-1}, \Delta T_{f}=1.79~K$. Formula: $\Delta T_{f} = K_{f} \times m \Rightarrow K_{f} = \frac{\Delta T_{f}}{m} = \frac{1.79~K}{0.15~mol~kg^{-1}} = 11.93~K~kg~mol^{-1}$.

question: Solution A contains 7 g/L of MgCl₂ and solution B contains g/L of NaCl. At room temperature, the osmotic pressure of...
question_latex: Solution A contains $7~g/L$ of $MgCl_{2}$ and solution B contains g/L of $NaCl$. At room temperature, the osmotic pressure of...
solution: According to Raoult's law: $\frac{p-p_{s}}{p} = \frac{n}{n+N} = \frac{0.05}{2.5+0.05} = \frac{0.05}{2.55} = \frac{1}{51}$. Weight of solute $= \frac{w}{w} \times M \times \frac{p}{p-p_{s}} = \frac{10 \times 18}{90} \times 51 = 102~g$.

question: Equal masses of methane and oxygen are mixed in an empty container at 25°C. The fraction of the total pressure exerted by oxygen is
question_latex: Equal masses of methane and oxygen are mixed in an empty container at $25^{\circ}C$. The fraction of the total pressure exerted by oxygen is
solution: Suppose equal mass $w = 1~g$. Mole fraction of oxygen $X_{O_2} = \frac{1/32}{1/32 + 1/16} = \frac{1/32}{3/32} = 1/3$. Pressure exerted by oxygen $= X_{O_2} \times P_{total} = P \times 1/3$.

question: If osmotic pressure of 0.2 M aqueous glucose solution is 5 atm at 300 K, calculate the concentration of glucose solution having osmotic pressure 2.5 atm at same temperature. [MHT-CET 2024: PCB]
question_latex: If osmotic pressure of 0.2 M aqueous glucose solution is 5 atm at 300 K, calculate the concentration of glucose solution having osmotic pressure 2.5 atm at same temperature. [MHT-CET 2024: PCB]
solution: Given: $M_{1}=0.2M, \pi_{1}=5~atm, \pi_{2}=2.5~atm$. Since $\pi = MRT$, for same temperature: $\frac{\pi_{1}}{\pi_{2}} = \frac{M_{1}}{M_{2}} \Rightarrow M_{2} = \frac{M_{1} \times \pi_{2}}{\pi_{1}} = \frac{0.2 \times 2.5}{5} = 0.1~M$.

question: Calculate the boiling point elevation of solution if 15 g urea is dissolved in 1000 g water. [Kb for water = 0.52 K kg mol⁻¹; molar mass of urea = 60 g mol⁻¹] [2025]

solution: $\Delta T_{b} = K_{b} \times m$. Moles of solute $= 15/60 = 0.25$. Mass of solvent $= 1~kg$. $m = 0.25~mol/kg$. $\Delta T_{b} = 0.52 \times 0.25 = 0.13~K$.

question: What is the molar mass of solute if 3 gram solute dissolved in 36 gram water? [Molar mass of H₂O = 18 g mol⁻¹ and relative lowering of vapour pressure is 0.025] [MHT-CET 2023: PCB]
question_latex: What is the molar mass of solute if 3 gram solute dissolved in 36 gram water? [Molar mass of $H_{2}O = 18~g~mol^{-1}$ and relative lowering of vapour pressure is 0.025] [MHT-CET 2023: PCB]
solution: Given: $W_{2}=3~g, W_{1}=36~g, M_{1}=18~g~mol^{-1}, RLVP = 0.025$. Formula: $RLVP = \frac{W_{2}M_{1}}{M_{2}W_{1}} \Rightarrow 0.025 = \frac{3 \times 18}{M_{2} \times 36} \Rightarrow M_{2} = \frac{3 \times 18}{0.025 \times 36} = 60~g~mol^{-1}$.

question: Calculate van't Hoff factor for formic acid if 0.01 m aqueous solution of formic acid freezes at -0.021 K and cryoscopic constant of water is 1.86 K kg mol⁻¹.
question_latex: Calculate van't Hoff factor for formic acid if $0.01\text{ m}$ aqueous solution of formic acid freezes at $-0.021\text{ K}$ and cryoscopic constant of water is $1.86\text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$.
solution: Given $m = 0.01\text{ m}$, $K_f = 1.86\text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$, and $T_f = -0.021\text{ K}$. \n $\Delta T_f = T_f^0 - T_f = 0 - (-0.021) = 0.021\text{ K}$. \n Using the formula $\Delta T_f = i \cdot K_f \cdot m$, we find $i = \frac{\Delta T_f}{K_f \cdot m} = \frac{0.021}{1.86 \times 0.01} = 1.129 \approx 1.13$.

question: What is the value of van't Hoff factor for 0.1 M Al2(SO4)3 solution if degree of dissociation is 80%?
question_latex: What is the value of van't Hoff factor for $0.1\text{ M } Al_2(SO_4)_3$ solution if degree of dissociation is $80\%$?
solution: $Al_2(SO_4)_3$ dissociates as $2Al^{3+} + 3SO_4^{2-}$, so $n = 5$. \n Given degree of dissociation $\alpha = 0.8$ ($80\%$). \n $i = 1 + \alpha(n - 1) = 1 + 0.8(5 - 1) = 1 + 3.2 = 4.2$.

question: Molar concentration of K2SO4 in a solution is 1 x 10⁻⁴ M. If the solution is 17.4 ppm, what is the density of the solution?
question_latex: Molar concentration of $K_2SO_4$ in a solution is $1 \times 10^{-4}\text{ M}$. If the solution is $17.4\text{ ppm}$, what is the density of the solution?
solution:
$17.4	ext{ ppm}$ means $17.4	ext{ g}$ of $K_2SO_4$ in $10^6	ext{ g}$ of solution. 
 The concentration $[K_2SO_4] = 1 	imes 10^{-4}	ext{ M}$ means $1 	imes 10^{-4}	ext{ moles/L}$. 
 Mass in 1L $= 1 	imes 10^{-4} 	imes 174	ext{ (molar mass)} = 0.0174	ext{ g/L}$. 
 Since $17.4	ext{ g}$ is in $10^6	ext{ mL}$ (assuming density $\approx 1$), $0.0174	ext{ g}$ is in $1000	ext{ mL}$.

question: The solubility of methane in benzene at 298 K under 760 mm Hg if KH = 4.27 x 10⁵ mm Hg is:

solution: According to Henry's law, $P = K_H \times x$. \n $x = \frac{P}{K_H} = \frac{760}{4.27 \times 10^5} = 1.779 \times 10^{-3} = 17.8 \times 10^{-4}$.

question: The freezing point of water is 273 K. What is the freezing point of a solution containing 5g of glucose in 100g of water? (Kf = 1.86 K kg mol⁻¹)
question_latex: The freezing point of water is $273\text{ K}$. What is the freezing point of a solution containing $5\text{g}$ of glucose in $100\text{g}$ of water? ($K_f = 1.86\text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$)
solution: $\Delta T_f = K_f \times \frac{W_2 \times 1000}{M_2 \times W_1} = 1.86 \times \frac{5 \times 1000}{180 \times 100} = 0.516\text{ K}$. \n $T_f = T_f^0 - \Delta T_f = 273 - 0.516 = 272.484\text{ K}$.

question: Calculate osmotic pressure of 0.2 M aqueous KCl solution at 0°C if van't Hoff factor for KCl is 1.83 . [R = 0.082 dm³ atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹] [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: Calculate osmotic pressure of 0.2 M aqueous KCl solution at $0^{\circ}C$ if van't Hoff factor for KCl is 1.83 . $[R = 0.082 \text{ dm}^3 \text{ atm mol}^{-1} \text{ K}^{-1}]$ [MHT-CET 2023]
solution:
Given: $M = 0.2 \text{ moldm}^{-3}$, $T = 0^{\circ}C = 273 \text{ K}$,
$R = 0.082 \text{ dm}^3 \text{ atm mol}^{-1} \text{ K}^{-1}$,
$i = 1.83, \pi = ?$
$\pi = iMRT$
$= 1.83 \times 0.2 \text{ moldm}^{-3} \times 0.082 \text{ dm}^3 \text{ atm mol}^{-1} \text{ K}^{-1} \times 273 \text{ K} = 8.2 \text{ atm}$

question: The solubility of a gas in liquid at a temperature is directly proportional to its
question_latex: The solubility of a gas in liquid at a temperature is directly proportional to its

question: Find the molar mass of solute when 1.6 gram solute dissolved in 16 gram solvent lowers its freezing point by 3.4 K . [Cryoscopic constant for solvent is 5.1 K kg mol⁻¹ ] [MHT-CET 2022 : PCB
question_latex: Find the molar mass of solute when 1.6 gram solute dissolved in 16 gram solvent lowers its freezing point by 3.4 K . [Cryoscopic constant for solvent is $5.1 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$ ] [MHT-CET 2022 : PCB
solution:
Given: $K_f = 5.1 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$, $W_2 = 1.6 \text{ g}$, $W_1 = 16 \text{ g}$, $\Delta T_f = 3.4 \text{ K}$, $M_2 = ?$
$\Delta T_f = K_f \times \frac{W_2 \times 1000}{M_2 \times W_1 \text{ in gram}}$
$M_2 = \frac{K_f \times W_2 \times 1000}{\Delta T_f \times W_1 \text{ in gram}}$
$= \frac{5.1 \times 1.6 \times 1000}{3.4 \times 16} = 150 \text{ g/mol}$

question: What is the molarity of 0.2 N Na2CO3 solution?
question_latex: What is the molarity of 0.2 N $Na_2CO_3$ solution?
solution:
Molarity = normality $\times \frac{\text{equivalent weight}}{\text{molecular weight}}$
Given, normality of $Na_2CO_3$ solution = 0.2 N
Equivalent weight = $M/2$ (Since $Na_2CO_3$ valency factor is 2)
Molecular weight $M$. 
$\therefore$ Molarity $= 0.2 \times \frac{M/2}{M} = 0.2 \times \frac{1}{2} = 0.1 \text{ M}$

question: Find the depression in freezing point of solution when 3.2 gram non-volatile solute with molar mass 128 gram mol⁻¹ is dissolved in 80 gram solvent if cryoscopic constant of solvent is 4.8 K kg mol⁻¹ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
question_latex: Find the depression in freezing point of solution when 3.2 gram non-volatile solute with molar mass 128 gram $mol^{-1}$ is dissolved in 80 gram solvent if cryoscopic constant of solvent is $4.8 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
solution:
Given: $W_2 = 3.2 \text{ g}$, $M_2 = 128 \text{ g mol}^{-1}$,
$W_1 = 80 \text{ g}$, $K_f = 4.8 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$, $\Delta T_f = ?$
$M_2 = \frac{1000 \cdot K_f \cdot W_2}{\Delta T_f \cdot W_1}$
$\therefore \Delta T_f = \frac{1000 \cdot K_f \cdot W_2}{M_2 \cdot W_1}$
$= \frac{1000 \text{ g kg}^{-1} \times 4.8 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1} \times 3.2 \text{ g}}{128 \text{ g mol}^{-1} \times 80 \text{ g}}$
$= 1.5 \text{ K}$

question: The vapour pressure will be lowest for _____.

question: At 80°C, the vapour pressure of pure liquid A is 520 mm Hg and that of pure liquid B is 1000 mm Hg. If a mixture solution of A and B boils at 80°C and 1 atm pressure, the amount of A in the mixture is (1 atm = 760 mm Hg)
question_latex: At $80^{\circ}C$, the vapour pressure of pure liquid $A$ is 520 mm Hg and that of pure liquid $B$ is 1000 mm Hg. If a mixture solution of $A$ and $B$ boils at $80^{\circ}C$ and 1 atm pressure, the amount of $A$ in the mixture is (1 atm = 760 mm Hg)
solution:
$P_T = P_A^0 X_A + P_B^0 X_B$
Mixture solution boil at 1 atm = 760 mm = total pressure.
$760 = 520 X_A + 1000(1 - X_A)$
$760 = 520 X_A + 1000 - 1000 X_A$
$480 X_A = 240$
$X_A = 0.5$, mol% of A = 50%

question: When is the molal elevation constant of solvent is equal the boiling point elevation? [2025]
question_latex: When is the molal elevation constant of solvent is equal the boiling point elevation? [2025]
options: A. Dissolve 1 g solute in 100 g solvent.
B. Dissolve 100 g solute in 1000 g solvent.
C. Dissolve 1 g mole solute in 1dm³ solvent.
D. Dissolve 1 g mole solute in 1 kg of solvent.
solution:
Molal elevation constant is the boiling point elevation produced by 1 molal solution.
$\Delta T_b = K_b m$. If $m = 1$, then $\Delta T_b = K_b$
Hence, molal elevation constant is equal to boiling point when 1 mole solute is dissolved in 1 kg of solvent.

question: What is the molar mass of solute if a solution is prepared by dissolving 4.5 gram solute in 3 dm³ water having osmotic pressure 0.25 atm at 300 K ? [ R = 0.0821 dm³ atm K⁻¹ mol⁻¹] [MHT-CET 2022 ]
question_latex: What is the molar mass of solute if a solution is prepared by dissolving 4.5 gram solute in 3 $dm^3$ water having osmotic pressure 0.25 atm at 300 K ? [ $R = 0.0821 dm^3 atm K^{-1} mol^{-1}$] [MHT-CET 2022 ]
solution:
Given : $W_2 = 4.5 \text{ g}, V = 3 \text{dm}^3, \pi = 0.25 \text{ atm}$,
$T = 300 \text{ K}$,
$R = 0.0821 \text{dm}^3 \text{ atm K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1}, M_2 = ?$
Molar mass of solute from osmotic pressure is given by,
$M_2 = \frac{W_2 R T}{\pi V}$
$= \frac{4.5 \text{ g} \times 0.0821 \text{ dm}^3 \text{ atm K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1} \times 300 \text{ K}}{0.25 \text{ atm} \times 3 \text{ dm}^3}$
$= 147.78 \approx 148 \text{ g mol}^{-1}$

question: A solution of nonvolatile solute is obtained by dissolving 1.5 g in 30 g solvent has boiling point elevation 0.65 K . Calculate the molal elevation constant if molar mass of solute is 150 g mol⁻¹ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
question_latex: A solution of nonvolatile solute is obtained by dissolving 1.5 g in 30 g solvent has boiling point elevation 0.65 K . Calculate the molal elevation constant if molar mass of solute is 150 g $mol^{-1}$ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
solution:
Given: $W_2 = 1.5 \text{ g}, W_1 = 30 \text{ g}, \Delta T_b = 0.65 \text{ K}$,
$M_2 = 150 \text{ g mol}^{-1}, K_b = ?$
$M_2 = \frac{1000 \cdot K_b \cdot W_2}{\Delta T_b \cdot W_1}$
$\therefore K_b = \frac{M_2 \cdot \Delta T_b \cdot W_1}{1000 \cdot W_2}$
$= \frac{150 \text{ g mol}^{-1} \times 0.65 \text{ K} \times 30 \text{ g}}{1000 \text{ g kg}^{-1} \times 1.5 \text{ g}}$
$= 1.95 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$

question:
Arrange the following equimolar solutions according to increasing order of osmotic pressure [Assume complete ionisation] [2025]
i) KCl
ii) BaCl2
iii) AlCl3
iv) Al2(SO4)3
question_latex:
Arrange the following equimolar solutions according to increasing order of osmotic pressure [Assume complete ionisation] [2025]
i) $KCl$
ii) $BaCl_2$
iii) $AlCl_3$
iv) $Al_2(SO_4)_3$
solution:
Osmotic pressure is a colligative property that depends on number of particles in solution. The solution having more number of particles will have large osmotic pressure. Suppose the concentration of each substance is 1 m.
i) $KCl \to K^+ + Cl^-$ (Total particles = 2 mol)
ii) $BaCl_2 \to Ba^{2+} + 2Cl^-$ (Total particles = 3 mol)
iii) $AlCl_3 \to Al^{3+} + 3Cl^-$ (Total particles = 4 mol)
iv) $Al_2(SO_4)_3 \to 2Al^{3+} + 3SO_4^{2-}$ (Total particles = 5 mol)
Hence, increasing order of osmotic pressure is $KCl < BaCl_2 < AlCl_3 < Al_2(SO_4)_3$

question: Which from following units of concentrations of solutions is temperature independent? [2025]
question_latex: Which from following units of concentrations of solutions is temperature independent? [2025]
solution: Among the given options, the mole fraction is the only concentration unit that is temperature independent because it is based on the ratio of moles, which doesn't change with temperature. All the other concentration units (molarity, percent by volume, and mass by volume) depend on the volume of the solution, and volume can change with temperature.

question: Calculate the solubility of gas in water at 25°C and 0.328 atm . [ KH = 0.159 moldm⁻³ atm⁻¹ at 25°C ] [MHT-CET 2023 : PCB
question_latex: Calculate the solubility of gas in water at $25^{\circ}C$ and 0.328 atm . [ $K_H = 0.159 \text{ moldm}^{-3} \text{ atm}^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ}C$ ] [MHT-CET 2023 : PCB
solution:

$S = K_H \cdot P$
$= 0.159 \text{ moldm}^{-3} \text{ atm}^{-1} \times 0.328 \text{ atm}$
$= 5.21 \times 10^{-2} \text{ mol dm}^{-3}$

question: On a humid day in summer, the mole fraction of gaseous a H2O (water vapour) in the air at 25°C can be as high as 0.0287. Assuming a total pressure of 0.977 atm. What is the partial pressure of dry air?
question_latex: On a humid day in summer, the mole fraction of gaseous a $H_2O$ (water vapour) in the air at $25^{\circ}C$ can be as high as 0.0287. Assuming a total pressure of 0.977 atm. What is the partial pressure of dry air?
solution:
$P_{H_2O} = X_{H_2O} P_{total}$
$= 0.0287 \times 0.977 = 0.028 \text{ atm}$
$P_{total} = P_{dryair} + P_{H_2O}$
$P_{dryair} = P_{total} - P_{H_2O}$
$= 0.977 - 0.028 = 0.949 \text{ atm}$

question: Calculate molality of solution of a non-volatile solute having boiling point elevation 1.89 K , if boiling point elevation constant of solvent is 3.15 K kg mol⁻¹ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
question_latex: Calculate molality of solution of a non-volatile solute having boiling point elevation 1.89 K , if boiling point elevation constant of solvent is $3.15 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
solution:
Given : $\Delta T_b = 1.89 \text{ K}, K_b = 3.15 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}, m = ?$
$\Delta T_b = K_b \times m \therefore m = \frac{\Delta T_b}{K_b} = \frac{1.89 \text{ K}}{3.15 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}} = 0.6 \text{ mol kg}^{-1}$

question: Calculate the mass of solute having molar mass 60 g mol⁻¹ dissolved in 100 gram solvent if boiling point elevation is 2 K and molal elevation constant for solvent is 2.5 K kg mol⁻¹ . [MHT-CET 2022 : PCB
question_latex: Calculate the mass of solute having molar mass 60 g $mol^{-1}$ dissolved in 100 gram solvent if boiling point elevation is 2 K and molal elevation constant for solvent is 2.5 K kg $mol^{-1}$ . [MHT-CET 2022 : PCB
solution:
Given : $M_2 = 60 \text{ g/mol}, W_1 = 100 \text{ g}, \Delta T_b = 2 \text{ K}, K_b = 2.5 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}, W_2 = ?$
$\Delta T_b = K_b \times \frac{W_2 \times 1000}{M_2 \times W_1 \text{ in gram}}$
$W_2 = \frac{\Delta T_b \times M_2 \times W_1 \text{ in gram}}{K_b \times 1000}$
$= \frac{2 \times 60 \times 100}{2.5 \times 1000} = 4.8 \text{ gram}$

question: The ' X ' g nonvolatile solute having molar mass 196 g mol⁻¹ is dissolved in 3dm³ water. Calculate the value of ' X ' if resulting solution has osmotic pressure 0.8 atm at 300 K . ( R = 0.0821 dm³ atm K⁻¹ mol⁻¹ ) [2025]
question_latex: The ' X ' g nonvolatile solute having molar mass 196 g $mol^{-1}$ is dissolved in $3dm^3$ water. Calculate the value of ' X ' if resulting solution has osmotic pressure 0.8 atm at 300 K . ( R = 0.0821 $dm^3$ atm $K^{-1}$ $mol^{-1}$ ) [2025]
solution:
$\pi = \frac{W_2 R T}{M_2 V}$
$\therefore W_2 = \frac{\pi M_2 V}{R T}$
$= \frac{0.8 \text{ atm} \times 196 \text{ g mol}^{-1} \times 3 \text{dm}^3}{0.0821 \text{ atm dm}^3 \text{ K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1} \times 300 \text{ K}}$
$= 19.098 \text{ g} \approx 19.1 \text{ g}$

question: If 6 g of solute dissolved in 100 g of water lowers the freezing point by 0.93 K . What is molar mass of solute? [Kf = 1.86 K kg mol⁻¹] [MHT-CET 2021 ]
question_latex: If 6 g of solute dissolved in 100 g of water lowers the freezing point by 0.93 K . What is molar mass of solute? [$K_f = 1.86 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$] [MHT-CET 2021 ]
solution:

question: What is the relation between molality of the solution and molar mass of solute? [MHT-CET 2022 ]
question_latex: What is the relation between molality of the solution and molar mass of solute? [MHT-CET 2022 ]
solution:
Molality (m) is defined as moles of solute per kg of solvent.
Moles of solute = $W_2 / M_2$
Mass of solvent in kg = $W_1 / 1000$
So, $m = \frac{W_2/M_2}{W_1/1000} = \frac{1000 \times W_2}{M_2 \times W_1}$

question: Which from following substances in their solutions of same concentration generates highest osmotic pressure?
question_latex: Which from following substances in their solutions of same concentration generates highest osmotic pressure?
solution:
Osmotic pressure depends on number of particles (colligative property). Highest i factor means highest osmotic pressure.
$KCl \to K^+ + Cl^-$ (2 particles)
$BaCl_2 \to Ba^{2+} + 2Cl^-$ (3 particles)
$Li_2SO_4 \to 2Li^+ + SO_4^{2-}$ (3 particles)
$Al_2(SO_4)_3 \to 2Al^{3+} + 3SO_4^{2-}$ (5 particles)
Hence, $Al_2(SO_4)_3$ has maximum number of particles.

question: The vapour pressure of two liquids X and Y are 80 and 60 Torr respectively. The total vapour pressure of the ideal solution obtained by mixing 3 moles of X and 2 moles of Y would be
question_latex: The vapour pressure of two liquids $X$ and $Y$ are 80 and 60 Torr respectively. The total vapour pressure of the ideal solution obtained by mixing 3 moles of $X$ and 2 moles of $Y$ would be
solution:
Mole of X, $n_x = 3$. Mole of Y, $n_y = 2$. Total moles = 5.
$X_x = 3/5, X_y = 2/5$.
$P_T = P_x^0 X_x + P_y^0 X_y$
$= 80 \times \frac{3}{5} + 60 \times \frac{2}{5}$
$= 48 + 24 = 72 \text{ Torr}$

question: A 0.5 m aqueous solution of monofluoroacetic acid freeze at -1.0 K . Calculate the van't Hoff factor of monofluoroacetic acid, if cryoscopic constant of water is 1.86 K kg mol⁻¹ . [MHT-CET 2023 : PCB
question_latex: A 0.5 m aqueous solution of monofluoroacetic acid freeze at -1.0 K . Calculate the van't Hoff factor of monofluoroacetic acid, if cryoscopic constant of water is 1.86 K kg $mol^{-1}$ . [MHT-CET 2023 : PCB
solution:
Given: $m = 0.5 \text{ m}$, $K_f = 1.86 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$,
$T_f = -1.0 \text{ K}$, $T_f^0 = 0 \text{ K}$, $i = ?$
$\Delta T_f = T_f^0 - T_f = 0 - (-1) = 1 \text{ K}$
$\Delta T_f = i \cdot K_f \cdot m$
$\therefore i = \frac{\Delta T_f}{K_f \cdot m}$
$= \frac{1 \text{ K}}{1.86 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1} \times 0.5 \text{ mol kg}^{-1}}$
$= 1.075 \approx 1.08$

question: The molal elevation constant for water is 0.52. What will be the boiling point of 2 molar sucrose solution at 1 atm pressure? (Assume b.p. of pure water is 100°C )
question_latex: The molal elevation constant for water is 0.52. What will be the boiling point of 2 molar sucrose solution at 1 atm pressure? (Assume b.p. of pure water is $100^{\circ}C$ )
solution:
$\Delta T_b = k_b \times \text{molality}$
For dilute solution, molarity $\approx$ molality = 2 (given) and $k_b = 0.52$
$\therefore \Delta T_b = 0.52 \times 2 = 1.04^{\circ}C$
Now, boiling point of solution = boiling point of solvent + $\Delta T_b$
$= 100 + 1.04 = 101.04^{\circ}C$

question: A solution of 6 g of solute in 100 g of water boils at 100.52°C . The molal elevation constant of water is 0.52 K kg mol⁻¹ . What is molar mass of solute? [MHT-CET 2021 ]
question_latex: A solution of 6 g of solute in 100 g of water boils at $100.52^{\circ}C$ . The molal elevation constant of water is $0.52 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$ . What is molar mass of solute? [MHT-CET 2021 ]
solution:
Given: $W_2 = 6 \text{ g}, W_1 = 100 \text{ g}$, $K_b = 0.52 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}, T_b = 100.52^{\circ}C$
$\Delta T_b = T_b - T_b^0$
$= (100.52 + 273) - (100 + 273) = 0.52 \text{ K}$ (Or just difference in Celsius)
$M_2 = \frac{1000 \cdot K_b \cdot W_2}{\Delta T_b \cdot W_1}$
$= \frac{1000 \cdot 0.52 \cdot 6}{0.52 \cdot 100}$
$= 60 \text{ g mol}^{-1}$

question: Density of a 2.05 M solution of acetic acid in water is 1.02 g/mL. The molality of the solution is
question_latex: Density of a 2.05 M solution of acetic acid in water is 1.02 g/mL. The molality of the solution is
solution:
Molality $(m) = \frac{M}{1000d - M M_1} \times 1000$
where $M$ = Molarity, $M_1$ = Molecular mass of solute (Acetic acid = 60), $d$ = density
$m = \frac{2.05}{(1000 \times 1.02) - (2.05 \times 60)} \times 1000$
$= \frac{2050}{1020 - 123} = \frac{2050}{897} = 2.28 \text{ mol kg}^{-1}$

question: Which from following pair of solutions is isotonic? [2025]
question_latex: Which from following pair of solutions is isotonic? [2025]
options: A. 6 gdm⁻³ urea and 17.1 gdm⁻³ sucrose
B. 3 gdm⁻³ urea and 17.1 gdm⁻³ sucrose

solution:
For isotonic solutions, the number of moles of solutes are equal (i.e., molar concentrations are same).

question: Calculate the solubility of a gas dissolved in water at 0.75 atm if the solubility of gas in water at 25°C and 1 atm is 6.85 x 10⁻⁴ mol dm⁻³ . [Henry's law constant is 6.85 x 10⁻⁴ mol dm⁻³ atm⁻¹] [MHT-CET 2022 : PCB
question_latex: Calculate the solubility of a gas dissolved in water at 0.75 atm if the solubility of gas in water at $25^{\circ}C$ and 1 atm is $6.85 \times 10^{-4} \text{ mol dm}^{-3}$ . [Henry's law constant is $6.85 \times 10^{-4} \text{ mol dm}^{-3} \text{ atm}^{-1}$] [MHT-CET 2022 : PCB
solution:
Given : $P = 0.75 \text{ atm}$,
$K_H = 6.85 \times 10^{-4} \text{ moldm}^{-3} \text{ atm}^{-1}, S = ?$
$S = K_H \times P = 6.85 \times 10^{-4} \times 0.75$
$= 5.14 \times 10^{-4} \text{ moldm}^{-3}$

question: Vapour pressure of a pure solvent is 550 mm of Hg . By addition of a non-volatile solute, it decreases to 510 mm of Hg . Calculate the mole fraction of solute in solution. [MHT-CET 2024 ]

question: In which of the following solutions, there will not be flow of solvent in either direction when separated by semipermeable membrane? [MHT-CET 2024 : PCB
question_latex: In which of the following solutions, there will not be flow of solvent in either direction when separated by semipermeable membrane? [MHT-CET 2024 : PCB
options: A. 6 g urea dm⁻³ and 36 g glucose dm⁻³
B. 18 g urea dm⁻³ and 18 g glucose dm⁻³
C. 6 g urea dm⁻³ and 18 g glucose dm⁻³
D. 6 g urea dm⁻³ and 24 g glucose dm⁻³
solution:
For no flow of solvent, solutions must be isotonic (same molarity).
In option C:
$M_{urea} = \frac{6 \text{ gdm}^{-3}}{60 \text{ g mol}^{-1}} = 0.1 \text{ M}$
$M_{glucose} = \frac{18 \text{ gdm}^{-3}}{180 \text{ g mol}^{-1}} = 0.1 \text{ M}$
$\therefore M_{urea} = M_{glucose}$. Solutions are isotonic and there will not be flow of solvent in either direction.

question: Which of the following solutions is a 1 M solution? C=12, H=1, O=16, Ca=39.98, Cl=35.5, Na=23)
question_latex: Which of the following solutions is a 1 M solution? $C=12, H=1, O=16, Ca=39.98, Cl=35.5, Na=23)$
options: A. 0.46 g of C2H5OH in 100 ml. of solution
B. 110.98 g of CaCl2 in 1000 mL of solution
C. 0.23 g of CH3OH in 100 mL of solution
D. 5.85 g of NaCl in 1000 mL of solution
solution:
Molar solution has 1 mole of solute in 1000 mL solution.
(B) Molar mass of $CaCl_2 = 39.98 + (2 \times 35.5) = 110.98 \text{ g}$.
Moles of $CaCl_2 = \frac{110.98}{110.98} = 1 \text{ mole}$.
Volume = 1000 mL = 1 L.
Molarity = 1 M.
(D) $NaCl$: Moles = 5.85/58.5 = 0.1 M.

question: Calculate the molal elevation constant if molality of solution is 0.34 mol kg⁻¹ . [ ΔTb = 0.68 K] [MHT-CET 2023 : PCB
question_latex: Calculate the molal elevation constant if molality of solution is $0.34 \text{ mol kg}^{-1}$ . [ $\Delta T_b = 0.68 \text{ K}$] [MHT-CET 2023 : PCB
solution:
Given : $\Delta T_b = 0.68 \text{ K}, m = 0.34 \text{ mol kg}^{-1}, K_b = ?$
$\Delta T_b = K_b m \therefore K_b = \frac{\Delta T_b}{m} = \frac{0.68 \text{ K}}{0.34 \text{ mol kg}^{-1}} = 2.0 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$

question: Calculate the vapour pressure of pure solvent if Δp is 50 mm Hg and mole fraction of solute is 0.08 . [2025]
question_latex: Calculate the vapour pressure of pure solvent if $\Delta p$ is 50 mm Hg and mole fraction of solute is 0.08 . [2025]
solution:
Relative lowering of vapour pressure,
$\frac{\Delta p}{P_1^0} = x_2$ (mole fraction of solute)
$\therefore P_1^0 = \frac{\Delta p}{x_2} = \frac{50 \text{ mmHg}}{0.08} = 625 \text{ mmHg}$

question: A solution of nonvolatile solute is obtained by dissolving 1 g in 100 g solvent, decreases its freezing point by 0.3 K . Calculate cryoscopic constant of solvent if molar mass of solute is 60 g mol⁻¹ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
question_latex: A solution of nonvolatile solute is obtained by dissolving 1 g in 100 g solvent, decreases its freezing point by 0.3 K . Calculate cryoscopic constant of solvent if molar mass of solute is 60 g $mol^{-1}$ . [MHT-CET 2023 ]
solution:
Given : $W_2 = 1 \text{ g}, W_1 = 100 \text{ g}, \Delta T_f = 0.3 \text{ K}, M_2 = 60 \text{ g mol}^{-1}, K_f = ?$
$M_2 = \frac{1000 \cdot K_f \cdot W_2}{\Delta T_f \cdot W_1}$
$\therefore K_f = \frac{M_2 \cdot \Delta T_f \cdot W_1}{1000 \cdot W_2}$
$= \frac{60 \text{ g mol}^{-1} \times 0.3 \text{ K} \times 100 \text{ g}}{1000 \text{ g kg}^{-1} \times 1 \text{ g}}$
$= 1.8 \text{ K kg mol}^{-1}$
